So Labor on a federal level are being condemned by state counterparts, by their youth wing and by us.

Much has been made of the opposition by unions to this deal, and rightly so. The whole rationale for union support of the Australian Labor Party is to ensure federal representation of the interests of workers. This bill before us today undermines that very objective. The Labor Party have perpetuated the furphy that wage reduction leads to more employment opportunities. How they intend to restrict this capitulation to junior workers and maintain that adult employment levels are not affected by wage elasticities escapes me. So the unions have every right to be worried and to be angry with a party which seems to have completely reneged on a large part of what it stands for.

As my colleague Senator Bartlett stated earlier in this debate, the ALP have come a very long way in a short time to clinch this deal and support this legislation. How some members of the opposition are reconciling their earlier comments with their actions last week is a complete mystery to all of us. How they will explain their support for this legislation to their constituents and at up-coming preselection contests is also a mystery. I have to exempt Senator George Campbell from that particular difficulty. He put, with great courage, his views on record yesterday, certainly explaining his concerns with this deal. I look forward to seeing him and other people who may share his concerns about discrimination on the basis of age crossing the floor, just as they urged me to do in 1996 when they put forward their amendments to the industrial relations legislation.

I understand that some unions have wanted to direct some members of the Labor Party to do that. That would be very interesting to see. In fact, it reminds me of Senator Sherry's quote from 1996. He exhorted me to cross the floor to support his amendment, and I challenge him to do the same. We might even move it to give him the opportunity to do that. Perhaps he will support an amendment along the lines of replacing junior rates with competency based wages. Perhaps he would simply like to come down here and explain what has happened on this road to Damascus, what has made him completely change his mind to completely contradict views that he put forward so stridently in this chamber in 1996.

That 1996 debate was heated; it was enraged. I was amazed at the level of invective and vitriol that was directed at my colleagues and me in this chamber, in particular from Senator Nick Sherry and, of course, Senator Lundy, who is the voice of youth. She is the youth spokesperson for the Australian Labor Party and even in March this year she referred to youth wages as a reflection of generational elitism, a charge she must now also bear. She spoke of her experiences as a young worker in making that comment.
Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

talk.start.para: —For Senator Collins, I will actually quote from Senator Lundy:

speech.para: As a 16-year-old I was able to enter the work force on adult wages. This provided me with an opportunity to participate in society with economic independence. . . I find myself in this place defending this simple notion of dignity for young people in the work force, defending this simple and fundamental right of young people to be able to get a job and be paid wages that are not discriminatory.
That is a great quote from Senator Lundy.

talk.start.para: —She's not in this place now.

—I will take that interjection, Senator Bartlett. Senator Lundy is not in this place now but I am sure that, in her role in this place of assisting the shadow minister for workplace relations, she will come down and speak to this legislation, which I do not think she could possibly be happy with, because I know there are certainly many members in the opposition who are not happy with this particular deal. Perhaps Senator Sherry is busy right now comparing notes with Senator Lundy. They are both absent today, certainly in sharp contrast to their behaviour on this issue in 1996.

speech.para: But, given the vacuum of information from the Labor Party defending this deal, I will explain why the Australian Democrats not only will oppose this but will not sell out on young people. We know there is no doubt that youth wages are discriminatory. No-one has disputed this fact. They contravene article 7 of the United Nations International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which we are signatories to. The existence of youth wages relies on an exemption from the antidiscrimination provisions of the Workplace Relations Act, and this situation will be perpetuated indefinitely, thanks to the Labor Party.

Youth wages—and this was put forward by Senator Campbell yesterday—are a historical accident in our workplaces. They emanate from a time when young people's incomes were determined according to the needs principle. They were never designed as an employment enhancement measure but because, in the words of the Argus newspaper back in 1926:

Boys only a few months from school in many walks of life are receiving wages which not many years ago were those of men with family responsibilities, while business, factory and shop girls in their teens are remunerated upon a scale which is a standing temptation to extravagance, thoughtlessness and irresponsibility.

These words appeared almost three-quarters of a century ago and, despite massive social and economic changes that have taken place in the interim, this is still the message which the old parties in this place are sending to young workers—this week in particular. The old parties have run a mile from the notion of comparative wage justice, leaving behind all the people who have supported them, forsaking the words they were uttering so boldly and proudly just two weeks ago, let alone almost three years ago during a comparable debate on this matter. No; the ALP is now content for young people to continue to be the only participants in the labour market who are paid according to their personal characteristics, not their skill, experience, expertise or education but their age—a discriminatory factor.

Much of the blame for the failure to expand wage based contractual training arrangements in Australia lies with inadequate wage structures and this bill, as my leader, Senator Meg Lees, has said, is a lost opportunity to improve young people's access to workplace training. Since the mid-1980s, no other OECD country has offered its young people fewer opportunities to acquire recognised vocational qualifications at the point of labour market entry than Australia. Current junior rates do not contain structured training or skill development components. As such, they provide the employer with a strong incentive to use the young employee merely in a productive capacity rather than as a learner and rather than allowing for training provisions. But minimal training provisions now are the legacy of this country as a consequence of these wage arrangements.

The ALP capitulation on this legislation precludes us from inserting training components into award determination provisions. Not only are the government and the opposition happy to condemn young workers to pittances of pay rates for work of equal value to their older colleagues; they are now preventing young people from accessing training opportunities while they are actually earning that pittance. Of course, many young workers work in low skilled occupations: 49.4 per cent of 15- to 19-year-olds work in the retail sector, 8.8 per cent in manufacturing, and 8.6 per cent in cafes and restaurants. Even more startling is the fact that the three large companies responsible for approximately one-third of youth employment are Coles Myer, Woolworths and McDonald's, company and franchises. They are responsible for most of the youth positions in the work force in this nation. I would be very interested to hear from the members of the opposition, hopefully, or government. Maybe they could try to argue that work in these companies under junior rates is highly skilled or that 15-year-olds are less proficient at making hamburgers or operating a supermarket checkout than 19-, 20- or 21-year-olds. Certainly Senator Andrew Murray has put on the record that there are examples of people up to 22-years-old being paid junior rates. How is it that we can possibly define a 22-year-old in our society as not being an adult, as being essentially a child, a junior?

I will put this on record once again for the Democrats, as we have done many times in public, in the chamber and in our submission to the IRC: we do not oppose the concept of differential wage rates and never have. We just believe that the determining factor in how you are paid should be your skill, your competency, your experience, your education, not your age, which is a discriminatory factor. This hot little deal that Senator Quirke is so proud of not only entrenches, indefinitely retains, junior wage rates in federal awards as they currently exist but, thanks to the case by case provisions, allows the extension. So the ALP is perpetuating, allowing, the notion that discrimination on the basis of age is okay. What a great message to send to not only young workers in our community but older workers. If they have really fallen for this correlation between wage rates and employment opportunities, what is to stop the ALP, in a deal with Mr Reith, capitulating once again and allowing reduced wage rates for older workers in order to allow for so-called employment opportunities?

I was interested to hear the response of the minister the other day to my question without notice on the issue of the need to protect small businesses through the retention and extension of youth rates. That is what his response was. The government has used the Productivity Commission inquiry into youth wages in support of its contention that low wages equal job creation. Yet this study excluded small business from its consideration although, perhaps, it counted McDonald's franchises, which sometimes, somehow, qualify as small businesses.

At this juncture, it might be useful to actually add some real evidence to the debate. The government has relied on four studies to support its position: the 1983 Bureau of Labour Market Studies study on youth wages and employment levels; the 1997 report of the Productivity Commission; the Australian Retailers Association survey of members; and, of course, the report of the IRC into junior rates of pay. The first three studies do not bear up particularly well to scrutiny. The BLMS report made no allowance for dynamics or different levels of technology in different workplaces and the impact of these factors in hiring decisions.

In addition to the aforementioned criticism of the Productivity Commission report of last year, it confuses male adult, adult female and junior data sets in its elasticity estimates. It does not discuss the relationship between changes in minimum wages for juniors and consequent changes in youth earnings. Even more interestingly, the Productivity Commission report manages to conclude on the one hand that there is no relationship between youth employment and youth wages, by finding that adult workers are complements rather than substitutes for youth in employment, and that adult employment will fall with any rise in youth wages. However, it also manages to find to the contrary as well, as expounded on many occasions by Peter Reith, who obviously did not read the rest of the report. Perhaps page 67 was the only page he read.

In the committee stage of this legislation I will expand on some of the difficulties with those other reports, identifying in particular the IRC report, which identifies the twin objectives of equal opportunity for young job seekers and equal treatment of employees, and concludes that age discrimination is a poor means of resolving these. I am sure we will hear many more examples and excerpts from the IRC report as we continue in this debate. But the Democrats have always favoured—and we are not ashamed of this—a case by case analysis to undertake the development and implementation of alternatives, those very alternatives that the commission was precluded from doing so.

On this matter, young people are not going to be sold out by the Australian Democrats on this issue, but they sure have been by a combination of the government and its dirty deal with the opposition. If you are going to defend doing deals, do better deals, but do not do deals that not only indefinitely retain youth wages in the 56 per cent of federal awards to which they already apply but then give Mr Reith exactly what he was after, and that is the opportunity to extend and to expand junior rates of pay to the other 44 per cent of awards that currently are not affected. It is a dirty deal and one that the constituents of the ALP, their members and their backbenchers are not going to forget. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In 1996 Senator Stott Despoja said in regard to the notion of discrimination on the basis of age:

speech.para: There is breathtaking hypocrisy in here this afternoon.

I think little has changed in 1999. We have to make it clear that in 1996 it was the Democrats who gave the numbers to the Reith-Kernot deal to extend the laws discriminating against young people and to keep youth wage discrimination on the statutes. That in turn has led to the situation where Labor can join with the government to keep the discrimination going.
What the Democrats did in 1996, Labor is doing in 1999. In 1996, former Senator Margetts from the Greens (WA) said:
Two years ago I thought the whole aspect of youth wages was based on the NIMTO principle—that is, Not In My Term of Office principle.
She noticed that that was continuing. She said:
It is time we bit the proverbial bullet.
She also said:
We finally have heard that it is not the Democrats preferred position—
that is, to keep youth wages going—
and it is basically to avoid a double dissolution that they are going against their own preferred position.
Senator Margetts went on to say:
This is no basis upon which a good decision should be made in the Senate.

I concur. So, of the parties in this place, only the Greens, right throughout this decade, have stood against the discrimination in wage fixing in this country against people on the basis of their age.

I agree with the content of the speeches of Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Murray and the other Democrats senators that we should not discriminate against people on the basis of their age. Wages should be fixed on the other parameters that have been so cogently put forward. But we cannot get away from the fact that this opportunity to keep the discrimination going is built on the basis that the Democrats established in this chamber in 1996. People who are aggrieved against youth wage discrimination continuing in this country are aggrieved because of the actions of the Democrats, and now the Labor Party, and always the coalition. Let us have that straight.

A fundamental argument is that we need to take money off some young people by not paying them adequately to create employment and training opportunities for other young people. It is a specious argument. There is a rapidly growing gap between the haves and the have-nots in this country. This legislation is an effort to keep in place the discrimination against the have-nots in our young working population.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to move a second reading amendment, which has been circulated. I move:

Omit all words after "That", substitute "this bill be not further proceeded with until separate legislation has been enacted to prevent corporations, which employ young people at rates less than those given to other employees who do similar work, from providing to any person a remuneration package in excess of $1,000,000 in any given year".

If we are going to take money from one lot of workers to create jobs or training for other people, surely we must start with the workers who have the most money. We are in a situation in Australia where there are now dozens of chief executive officers taking home more than $1 million each year in their package.

Let me refer to an article by Jody Scott in the Australian of 9 August this year headed, `Fat cats grow fatter as they roll in their options'. There is a chart in that article labelled `Top of the tree' which lists Australia's highest paid chief executives. I will read from that chart:
. Frank Lowy, Westfields Holdings, $6.44 million—
this is in one year—
. George Trumbull, former AMP chief executive, $4.95 million
. Paul Batchelor, new AMP boss, salary yet to be settled
. Dennis Eck, Coles Myer, $3.3 million
. Rob Ferguson, Bankers Trust, $3.25 million
. Robert Kirby, Village Roadshow, $3.2 million
. Allan Moss, Macquarie Bank, $3.1 million
. David Morgan, Westpac, multi-million dollar salary plus proposed $32.49 million share options performance package
. John McFarlane, ANZ, $2.77 million—

and on it goes. We go right down to Gerry Harvey at Harvey Norman who is on $250,000 but owns a 33 per cent stake in the Harvey Norman empire worth $1.03 million. I am not for a communistic principle which says, in the worst of enforced dictum, that everybody shall get exactly the same amount. I believe in free enterprise.

talk.start.para: —A huge concession.
—You've come out on this one.
—We are getting some government input to the debate now. They might be able to bring up some of these matters with President Jiang Zemin, the communist leader they will be entertaining next week.

speech.para: However, in the meantime, the Greens believe that everybody should get a guaranteed adequate income which makes sure that they have an opportunity, in particular, to be in the work force. What we do not accept is that we should be here locking in discriminatory wages against young Australians while doing nothing about these obscene income packages going to a handful of super-rich people. We are in a world where 535 individuals own as much of the wealth as the 1½ billion poorest people on the planet. That is out of control. That needs legislative action. That needs politicians with guts. That needs a government with principle. I find that the prospect of locking in here again discrimination against young people, who are getting very tiny wages compared to these packages, with no mention—except for a Green intervention—of these people because of the influence that they have over the political domain in this country, is quite extraordinary. We will see how we go with that amendment.

Senator Murray has made it abundantly clear why we do not have a desperate need to get this legislation through here today. We do have ample time to adopt this Greens amendment and look at least at balancing legislation. After all, the amendment which the Greens have moved will affect far fewer Australians than the legislation we have before us now. It will be a restraint on wages for far fewer people in Australia than would be the case under this legislation. So, whatever argument might be put about the discriminatory nature of it, it pales into insignificance when compared with the number of people that this discriminatory legislation we have before us will affect.

I oppose the legislation. I hope Labor will reconsider. I accept the contributions from the Democrats as genuine. It is a pity, however, that the Reith-Kernot deal occurred when it did. It is a blot on the historic record as far as the Democrats' avocation to ending discrimination in the workplace is concerned. But we cannot ignore it because, without it, we would not be here today enabling this discrimination to continue.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It has been a fascinating debate. I must say that I think a number of senators have actually risen to the bait. What the Democrats seem to fail to under stand is that the reason the Labor Party has rolled over on this is not so much because it just thought that it had to do something different for a change; it is because it had nowhere else to go, because all the logic takes you inexorably in this direction.

speech.para: Rabid zealots like Senator Brown—who regard international conventions as ends in themselves irrespective of the consequences for ordinary citizens, let alone young people—will of course never countenance any compromise on these issues. But the fact is, however, that, if we look at the situation in the UK, we see that the UK Low Pay Commission concluded that:
Those in the youth labour market—

talk.start.para: —They don't want the UK, do they?
—Well, it is a nice, friendly Labour government over there.
—No; I said, `They don't want the UK, do they?'
—Well, of course; they don't want anything except zealotry. The UK Low Pay Commission concluded:

speech.para: Those in the youth labour market or trying to enter that market are among the most vulnerable in the work force. Above all else, they need work, and they need work which will allow them to acquire basic skills to enable them to develop. In any case, of course, low pay is a transitory experience for most junior employees. Under the junior rates system, employees can expect to progress to higher paid jobs every year providing they remain in employment. When they develop the skills and experience, they can compete successfully for jobs that are paid at adult rates.

I was intrigued to hear Senator Stott Despoja rabbiting on about the right to be not discriminated against. But, of course, what that UK report says so eloquently is that they have an even greater right, and that is a right to a job. They would much prefer to have money in their pockets and food on the table than to have some sort of high-minded principle when in the dole queue.

What is very difficult for the Democrats to come to terms with is that they pushed long and hard for the very inquiry that has now come down and comprehensively rejected their position. The series of amendments that they have proposed were all considered and rejected by the AIRC. Indeed, the whole notion of a competency based wage system has been comprehensively rejected by the independent umpire. The commission found that none of the non-discriminatory alternatives to junior rates put to it were feasible. Competency based classifications were not even the best of the bunch of options available. They said that there was an indisputable relationship between junior rates, their possible abolition and the employment prospects of young people.

The Democrats' proposal is that the replacement of the age based structure with a competency based model should not be on a lowest common denominator basis. They argue that young people must be given the same wage as an entry level adult would expect to receive. This would mean that the cost of employing a 15-year-old, employed under typical junior rates, would increase 150 per cent; for a 16-year-old, 100 per cent; for a 17-year-old, 67 per cent; and, for an 18-year-old, 40 per cent. I do not think there can be much doubt on any of those numbers that no employer in his or her right mind would regard the fact that someone happened to be 15 and not deserving to be discriminated against as a sufficient reason to pay those sorts of premiums.

Quite clearly the whole notion of age does equate with experience. We all know that in our own lives. The AIRC recognises it, as do young people. Of course there are professional industry advocates who want to run the line that somehow young people support ongoing discrimination against their right to work. But as to this notion that is being trotted out by the Australian Democrats that somehow 22-year-olds do not deserve to be discriminated against, the fact is that only one federal award of nearly 1,700 surveyed by the AIRC has a junior rate for a 21-year-old. So the bill leaves the ages to which junior rates apply to be determined by the commission on a case by case basis.

talk.start.para: —It was 22, not 21.
—There is only one for 22. Okay, my note is wrong, but that is consistent with the proposition I am advancing. I defer to that.

speech.para: I understood that the Democrats—at least Senator Stott Despoja, who presumably does not speak for the Democrats on many of these issues—were nonetheless arguing that the Democrats supported a case by case assessment. If that is the case, it is quite extraordinary that the very report which they called for for so long and which comprehensively rejects their position should only be touched on with the merest feather by Senator Stott Despoja. You can throw around terms like `sell out of young people' as much as you like, but the fact is that what the Labor Party has done is actually to stand up to the trade union movement. It is only for five minutes. It is only a tactical retreat. No-one for a moment thinks that this signals a new era of independence. They still remain wholly owned subsidiaries. We only had to see this parade of people jumping up to demonstrate their union credentials to show—

talk.start.para: —Where?
—We had Senator Campbell, Senator Hogg—
—Two.
—Who else was there? Senator Quirke.
—Three.

—That is three out of probably five people in the chamber at the time. Senator Campbell was not able to speak because he was in the chair. They are falling over themselves to demonstrate that they have not lost faith with the cause. It is pretty clear what the union movement expect for their investment, for putting all these people in parliament. They expect some return and they do not think they are getting it.

speech.para: `I cannot understand why the ALP would be embracing a key element of the deregulated labour market agenda of the Liberals' is about the only statement of principle I have seen. Your beloved Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association national secretary said, `I think as a union we have got to review our relationship. This goes to show you cannot rely on the Labor Party to represent your point of view in parliament.' In other words, what he is saying is, `They have always been in our back pocket. We have always been able to rely on them 100 per cent, but now there is a bit of a doubt.' In other words, `Gosh, maybe they are not the mouthpieces that we paid them to go into parliament to be.' I can understand why he is very concerned. He will be wanting his money back at the next preselection round, probably so he can come in and have a go himself. It would probably be a pay increase.

There is a whole litany of unionists who are very, very annoyed. Jennie George—and I suppose Senator Stott Despoja thinks she deserves a seat in the state parliament of New South Wales but I doubt that many people on the Labor Party side do—is here again claiming that union leaders—and I suppose the feminist network does, do they, Senator Collins?

talk.start.para: —What was that?
—They think that Jennie George should get a seat in the upper house in New South Wales.
—No idea.
—No? No idea. No comment.
—No idea.
—No idea? That is even worse—not interested.
—She would make a first-class parliamentarian.
—This is very worrying, Senator Murray. You have obviously been spending too much time with the ACTU.
—Minister, it might help if you directed your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Of course, she expressed the claim that, `Union leaders had unanimously expressed deep concern and disappointment. The unions were very angry at the ALP. We are supposed to be on the same side.' But of course Mr Crean reassured them that this was only really a little blip. He said, `These things will heal. What we have to do is try and find a position that can actually get the numbers in the parliament and then ensure an agenda that the government was hell-bent on introducing is not carried out and that we succeeded in.' I am not quite clear what he is saying there. `We are supporting junior wage rates until we get the numbers in parliament when we will do what you ask us to do and repeal them'? Not very inspiring stuff. If this whole backflip strategy is designed to enable Mr Beazley to go out there and say, `Look, I stood up to them; I am not the wholly owned doormat you thought I was. I am not simply trotting out to everything that the union movement asks us. I have taken on the full raft of our employers,' it is sending a mixed message, isn't it?

speech.para: I suppose the answer to all that is that Mr Beazley says one thing and Mr Crean says another. We are happy to regard that as healthy competition. Senator Campbell has made it plain with his actions in recent days. He has got nowhere else to go, and I suspect a lot more people will be going in that same direction. The union movement lives in hope that Mr Crean will get up and reverse this deal. But for the time being at least, we applaud the Labor Party's morality on this issue.

talk.start.para: —Have you read Mr Crean's statements on this?
—Yes. I just quoted one of them. He said to the union movement, `Don't worry. As soon as we've got the numbers, we'll fix it up for you.' That is probably sufficient for our purposes.

speech.para: I do not have anything more to say on the subject. The evidence is overwhelming. Anyone who reads the AIRC report will understand that there is no way to approach this issue other than to put the rights of young workers to a job ahead of any other consideration. We are delighted that at least the Labor Party acknowledges that.

talk.start.para: —In relation to Senator Brown's amendment in the second reading stage, I want to put on the record that Labor does share Senator Brown's concerns on the issue of executive salaries, but it is ludicrous to link that issue to junior rates. On that basis, we will not be supporting this amendment.
—The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Brown be agreed to.

interjection.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Bill read a second time.
The bill.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to the first amendment I am putting, on sheet 1524. I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 10), at the end of paragraph (aa), add "while seeking, as far as possible, to eliminate discrimination in pay rates on the basis of age".

This amendment affects the principal object. It seeks to ensure that the objects of the act give full weight to parliament's desire to ensure that discrimination on the basis of age is inappropriate. Unless the objective of this paragraph is clearly made apparent—that it is about balancing youth employment issues and age based discrimination—then this objective would, in our view, be in direct conflict with objective (j) of the act.

The Democrats regard the issue of age based discrimination as a fundamental threshold for this chamber to consider. Right at the heart of this issue is the view which we hold and which Australians share that people should not be discriminated against on the grounds of age, race, sex, gender, religion, disability and so on. The government's riposte to that is that it is appropriate to discriminate against young people on the basis of age with respect to jobs because without it they would lose those jobs. That case has not been proven. Even if it were accepted as a legitimate view and even if the Australian population as a whole accept the idea that 15-year-olds should be paid at a lower rate than adults—and that is what the Australian population believes—the Australian population does not accept that age based discrimination is appropriate with people once they achieve adult status.

Minister, you made the remark that in my public commentary I have been deliberately referring to the extreme—namely, that there are people in awards aged 22 who are discriminated against in terms of youth rates. I believe that in your response at the end of the second reading debate you indicated that that was only one of thousands. I do not know if it is only one of thousands, frankly, because I have not checked every single one. I do know that in the junior rates inquiry No. 33985 of 1998, in an attachment to the joint government submission, was a list of 100 federal awards which had been surveyed for the purpose of that inquiry. In that survey, they identified that those 100 broke up as follows. There were nine awards at age 18, two between age 18 and 21, one at age 19, two at age 19 and 20, 10 at age 20, eight at age 20 and 21, 43 at age 21 and one at age 22. I do not know whether that is the one you are referring to or whether you are referring to what is in the thousands of awards. The point I want to make is really expressed in those figures. Of all Australian awards that have junior wages provisions—and, according to that survey, three-quarters of all federal awards have junior wages provisions—70 per cent are from age 20 to 22 and nearly all of them are at the age of 21. That is behind the resistance of the government to lowering the ceiling and that is behind the resistance of the Labor Party leaders to lowering the ceiling.

We think it is unconscionable that adults of 21 and 22, who form the bulk of the people in junior rates awards, should be paid youth rates. It is unjustifiable discrimination. It ranks on the same level of discrimination, in our view, as those age-old beasts that we have largely defeated: that women should be discriminated against, that Jews should be discriminated against, that black people should be discriminated against—that people who are different to us should be discriminated against. The very arguments—we say this every time and it is refuted every time—used to preserve youth rates at an unacceptably high level were those used in the debate about women having equal pay.

This is not an argument about jobs. In our view, it is an argument about unjustifiable discrimination and whether adults should be paid adult wages. Every quote we produce from the unions and from the Labor Party has that view. I am fairly certain, given what the Liberal Party referred to as the broad church of their views, that there are people within their membership as well who hold that view.

talk.start.para: —You don't believe that.

—I do believe it. I will argue that it is appropriate to have youth rates for 15-year-olds who do not have the skills and experience necessary. I accept that argument. I accept the argument, and I have done so publicly on behalf of the Democrats, that it is appropriate for the Industrial Relations Commission to consider these issues on a case by case basis. I have said so. Section 143(1)(E) of the act specifically permits that. I have said that it is appropriate for the commission to develop relativities because it is clear that very young people do not have the competencies, skills, experience and abilities of adults with respect to their particular employment level. That is not the issue for us. The issue for us is that you want to pay adults youth rates.

speech.para: The survey I spelt out says that 57 per cent of the three-quarters of all awards that have youth rates are at the age of 21. It is an anachronism, it is old-fashioned, it is old-time. We are out of touch, we are out of kilter, with the rest of the OECD on this. This isn't some kind of freaky argument. This is an argument that has been accepted throughout the OECD. Only two countries—the Netherlands and Australia—permit youth rates to go to the age of 22. We should be ashamed of ourselves. Even New Zealand, the bastion of free market economic rationalism, sets a ceiling of 19. That is at the core of this argument and the core of this issue. That is why we feel strongly about it. We feel it is unjustifiable discrimination on unjustifiable grounds, like when people are Catholics or Jews or black or females. How can you possibly discriminate against a 21-year-old? How can you say that a 21-year-old is not an adult? Frankly, I feel like I am speaking a foreign language. I cannot comprehend how Australians and Australian parliamentarians, holding to the values and culture and truths and decent values that they do, can contemplate paying 21-year-olds kids' rates.

talk.start.para: —Because they are being trained.

—Oh, please! We have training legislation which covers that. I have no objection whatsoever to somebody who is in training being paid a lower wage. Of course that is right. If I go to learn to be a nuclear scientist tomorrow and I am in year 1 of my course, even though I am in my 50s, I will accept that I should get a lower wage. Of course I accept that. The Democrats are not arguing that. They are arguing that, where a trainee scheme does not exist and where people are doing adult work, they should be paid adult pay; that's all. It is very simple. That is what lies behind our approach.

speech.para: The government say—and I understand this—that they are afraid that, if they shift the ceiling down, people will lose jobs because their wages will go up. We answer: that is what you said about women, and it did not happen. We answer that the federal legislation is one of six legislative jurisdictions, that the percentage of young people affected by this legislation is relatively low and that you can afford to start to lower that ceiling.

Anyway, back to this matter of discrimination and pay rates on the basis of age. The coalition has held a consistent view on this, but Labor's view was different. Labor was moving towards our position. In Working Nation in 1994—five years ago, so it is a long held position—the white paper, which I understand was largely written by the very capable Simon Crean, said the following:
The government supports the transition over time to competency based arrangements from the current system of age based wages for young people.

I think that is a very straightforward, sensible statement. This has continued to be Labor policy for the last five years. In December 1998, when Peter Reith, the minister, started his push to repeal the provisions he had agreed to two years before, Mr Beazley endorsed the view of the shoppies union head Joe de Bruyn, who said:
. . . the real issue being that with junior rates you have got discrimination, and that is simply not acceptable in society today.

Mr Beazley said that that view was a sensible position. On 10 February 1999, his shadow employment spokesperson and former ACTU President, Martin Ferguson, was urging the House to `examine and read in detail the submission from the shop assistants' union to the junior rates inquiry'. Mr Ferguson said:
Whilst acknowledging that in some cases there is a need potentially for junior rates of pay—
which incidentally, as an aside, the Democrats do not disagree with—

but not across industry in general, it argues that equal work for equal pay is an important principle. If two people are standing side by side doing work of equal value, why should they be paid differently just because one is 18 and the other 28 or 38? That is the real issue before the chair today.
That is what Mr Ferguson said. He went on to say:
I am not prepared to stand by and allow employers to discriminate against young people . . .

That is what he is doing. I am in complete agreement with his former remarks, but now he and the rest of the leaders of the Labor Party are forcing Labor members and senators to agree to a position which I know many of them cannot in all honesty and integrity support. Our amendment here seeks to ensure that in any case by case analysis the age discrimination issue is given equal billing with the youth employment issue. It seeks to ensure that new objective (aa) reads comfortably alongside existing objective (j) and that discrimination on the basis of age is permissible only to the extent necessary to promote youth employment.

If I understand those within the government ranks who have a moral view of these things, that is what they say to me. They say they only want discrimination to the extent necessary to promote youth employment. I might disagree with them on the empirical basis of that argument but—if that is their argument and that is what moral coalition speakers feel—our amendment allows the IRC to make that appropriate adjustment. That is the right and proper basis on which case by case analysis can proceed and, in our view, it would assist the IRC to fulfil its duties under the case by case provisions.

talk.start.para: —I am going to make a fairly brief contribution to this debate—in part, at least, in response to the comments made by Senator Stott Despoja and a number of others. I will point out for the record that if I sound a little less than enthusiastic it is not because I am not enthusiastic. As I explained to Senator Stott Despoja, I have a fairly bad case of the flu.
—You stay far away then!

—You are far enough away. That is why I am not going to get as impassioned as I did when I spoke on this matter in 1996. I have not followed the entire debate to date, but I noticed in the Hansard record that Senator Allison did make a reference also to my comments in 1996 on this issue of junior wage rates. For the record, I should point out to Senator Allison that I was not a former official of the Miscellaneous Workers Union. Prior to entering parliament I was a member of what was commonly known as the liquor and allied trades union.

speech.para: I would also like to say to Senator Stott Despoja that, whilst the criticisms I made of the Democrats in 1996 were strong and firm, I do not think I was unnecessarily personal. I hope you will accept that. I do recall making a comment comparing Senator Stott Despoja with Boadicea; I think that is as personal as it got. Frankly, within the range of exchanges we have in this chamber, I think that was fairly restrained. Senator Stott Despoja does know the limits which I exercise in terms of making personal criticisms of people making contributions in debates.

The reason we are here today, of course, is that the position and the arguments advanced by Labor in 1996 that we should remove junior wage rates were rejected by the Australian Democrats. It was the Australian Democrats who entered into an agreement with the government on the first wave of industrial relations—

talk.start.para: —Led by Cheryl Kernot.

—It was the Australian Democrats. They agreed on a package that Labor vehemently disagreed with—not, I might say, just in respect of junior rates of pay but in respect of a range of other changes that were made to the industrial relations legislation at that time. We are back here today debating this issue of junior wage rates because at that time the Australian Democrats did a deal with the government, a deal that I had—and still have—strong views about. Indeed, as I recall, it was the Australian Democrats who proposed the compromise that the issue of junior rates of pay should be referred to the Industrial Relations Commission for examination and report, and that is what has happened.

speech.para: What happened as a consequence of the Democrats-Liberal government deal of that time? The commission heard the evidence— and, apparently, it heard a direct contribution from the Australian Democrats—and it rejected the proposition. I think it is particularly unfortunate that the commission has rejected the proposition that there should be a unilateral abolition of junior wage rates. It rejected it. I do think that is unfortunate. It is not a view that I would hold, but that is the position.

I will get to what is even more pertinent. Since 1996, in the first wave we saw the beginning of the stripping back of the independence of the commission in a number of areas. The second wave of the industrial relations legislation takes that even further with the continual stripping back and with restrictions being placed on the independent Industrial Relations Commission. That is a very important issue, and certainly in my view it is the most critical of issues. It is the independence of the commission that is continually being challenged and restricted. I think that if the coalition stays in government long enough we are going to have a third wave—and perhaps a fourth wave—where we effectively will not have a commission at all. For a whole lot of reasons, which I will not go into detail about today, I think that would be enormously detrimental to the future of Australian workers.

So it is that principle of the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission and the preservation of the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission that I think is the most important issue now—at this point in time—in this debate. As a Labor senator, if I were to support a proposition that we unilaterally abolish junior wage rates—I think you have to consider that issue—that would be counter to what I think is the central and most important principle at this point in time: the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission and maintaining a strong Industrial Relations Commission that does have the power and authority to act across the entire front of industrial relations. For that reason I think a great deal has changed since the original debate in 1996, including the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. Regrettably, the commission has taken a view that the proposition advanced by the Australian Democrats should be rejected. I am one of those who take the view, `You may not like the umpire's decision but that is the decision the umpire has given us since 1996.'

Of course, there is a big difference now with respect to the government's position. Minister Reith was originally advancing the proposition that junior rates should unilaterally be imposed on every award in Australia, presumably those industries where you do not have junior rates of pay—from memory, a couple of them are the construction industry, the transport industry and even my old industry, the hospitality industry. Minister Reith was effectively advocating, for example, that people who serve liquor should be paid junior rates of pay. The relevance of that is that in the liquor industry, the hospitality industry, the commission determined that if you were serving alcohol at the age of 18 you would be paid adult rates of pay—and I think the commission took a very sensible position. Yet the position of Minister Reith was that if juniors are serving alcohol, they should be paid junior rates of pay and that even adults between the ages of 18 and 21 should be paid junior rates of pay to serve alcohol. I think that would be absolutely absurd. And I think that is one of the reasons why issues on junior rates should be left to the commission to look at on an industry by industry basis. We had Minister Reith advocating that you insert junior rates of pay into every award in the country. I just think that was absurd.

What is the position today? Minister Reith was quite wrong yesterday—and I will not use the sort of language that will be ruled unparliamentary—in grossly misleading the Australian public and the parliament about Labor's position. Labor have accepted the reality of the situation we find ourselves in today. We have accepted that reality. Circumstances have changed since 1996. We now have a commission report with appropriate recommendations. The legislation we are dealing with will leave it to the commission to determine the position of junior rates of pay in awards—award by award. That is a very significant difference from the proposition being advanced by Minister Reith—publicly at least—until a couple of weeks ago.
There is one other point I would like to make about junior rates of pay. There is an element—

talk.start.para: —Are you going to ask a question?

—Yes, of course. As I recall, I am just following Senator Murray's particular contribution, which was not ruled out of order. So there is an element of duplicity and double standard in the Democrats' position—I say that without it, I hope, being taken as too personal—because they are arguing very angrily about junior rates of pay, but in fact what the Democrats have been doing to our industrial relations system in the first wave and the second wave, by the changes they have been agreeing to, has been slowly but surely weakening the bargaining position of workers vis-a-vis the employer. That is the outcome of the particular changes that they have agreed to with respect to the first wave—and I certainly hope they do not do so with respect to the second wave.

speech.para: Who is the most disadvantaged as a result of these outcomes? Obviously all workers are disadvantaged to some degree or other. But it is in fact younger people who are disadvantaged as a result of these changes, because it is younger people—and I am speaking here only generally—who do not have the level of industrial knowledge that perhaps someone who is older would have and their bargaining position is considerably weakened as a result of that. So the Democrats are putting forward a position about junior rates of pay which is very inconsistent with the position that they have been adopting with the government in weakening the bargaining position of Australian workers, because it is younger people who will be most disadvantaged as a result of the weaker bargaining position of Australian employees.

It is not my intention to speak any longer. I wish I could. We had two weeks on this issue and on industrial relations changes in 1996. Despite what may at times be provocation from Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Murray, they do well know that we have a time limit on this debate—and I just point that out to the chamber. They well know that my Senate colleague Senator Collins—and I watched her very effective and knowledgeable contribution yesterday—is handling the legislation for us. So, regrettably, I will have to restrain my contribution if we are to deal with this matter in a reasonably timely way and get on to another piece of legislation that I am also personally quite anxious about: the RFA legislation, which we will be hoping to finish tonight as well.

With those remarks, I do accept that from time to time within the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement there will be differences. I do not resile from that. I was a former trade union official, and I reject the comments from Senator Alston that we are the lap-dogs of the trade union movement. That is wrong. When you come into this place you have a different political master, and that master is the Australian public and the Australian Labor Party. That is the reality, Senator Alston, and I have explained my position.

talk.start.para: —Will you be circulating your remarks to all the relevant unions?

—I was just about to say, Senator Alston, that I have had a number of trade union officials contact me about this. I have explained the position to them. I have explained why the Australian Labor Party has taken a particular position and I have explained my view on the matter. I do not resile from that, and hopefully they respect my view. I do not always agree with former trade union colleagues. In any organisation with a reasonable level of democracy you just have to agree to disagree at times. We do not always do what the trade union movement want, but we respect their contribution and their views. On many occasions our views will be similar, but it does not always happen. That is healthy in a democracy and it is certainly healthy in the Australian Labor Party. I have said that privately and I say it publicly now to the extent that this debate is public. (Time expired)

—The amendment moved by Senator Murray on behalf of the Australian Democrats seeks to ensure that the objects of the act give full weight to parliament's desire to ensure that discrimina tion on the basis of age is inappropriate. I would like to respond to a couple of comments from the minister and from members of the opposition in relation to the AIRC's report. People have used terms such as `comprehensive rejection' in relation to the possibility of determining feasible alternatives to wage rates determined by age. I refer honourable members to the relevant chapter, chapter 7, of that inquiry report. In particular, I will read from the summary of that report, which I do not shy away from. I think that to suggest that it is comprehensively rejecting the notion that there should be an alternative to wages based on age is quite a misrepresentation. Point 2 of the summary of that report says:

speech.para: The essence of our report is that none of the identified non-discriminatory alternatives most closely examined by us were feasible.
Those alternatives put to the inquiry were not considered feasible. I do not dispute that. The report continues:
We give our reasons in Chapter 7 in the body of the report. We do not close off the possibility that there are feasible alternatives.
That is very different from a `comprehensive rejection' of the notion of alternatives being available or being able to be developed.
We do not close off the possibility that there are feasible alternatives.
The report goes on to say:
We explored the possibility of developing our own proposal but did not persevere. We were already persuaded that in the design of replacement of junior rate classifications no one size fits all.

I do not think there would be an argument from anyone in this chamber—certainly not from the Democrats—on that notion, and that is why the Democrats have said that we support the idea of case by case assessments and assessments on merit. The summary continues:
The fit of an alternative is a matter of attention to detail and the merits in particular circumstances.
Indeed. It continues:
The industrial parties and other interested parties would need to be involved, and that procedure—
and here is the clincher—
fell outside the statutory limits of our inquiry.

It is very wrong for this chamber to conclude that the IRC have comprehensively rejected the notion of alternatives or said that alternatives are not feasible and cannot be developed. They have not said that, and it is a blatant misrepresentation of the inquiry's findings to suggest otherwise.

I am sure that members of the government and the opposition know that, but I have found the government's analysis of the AIRC report into youth wages to be continually flawed. It has obviously been a convenient justification and defence of not only this decision but also the previous position of the government, to which Senator Sherry referred. He was quite right in denouncing the original proposal put forward by the minister responsible, and that was the notion of mandating in all awards that the junior rate should apply. Had members of the old parties read beyond the bold type in that report they would have discovered that the possibility of developing feasible alternatives was never closed off, but that the IRC concluded that the statutory limits to its inquiry precluded it from developing its own proposal.

As I mentioned briefly in my earlier remarks, the report identifies the twin objectives of equal opportunity for young job seekers and equal treatment of employees, and concludes that age discrimination is a poor means of resolving these. The commission finds against an immediate or general removal of junior wage rates, but not against their gradual replacement.

The report refers to—as indeed have the Democrats—case by case analysis to undertake the development and implementation of alternatives that the commission was precluded from doing. We recognise that this process may be lengthy and unwieldy, but the Democrats believe that the injustices caused by age based wages, such as an hourly wage rate of just $3.06 under the graphic arts interim award, must be redressed. We recognise that it is going to be complex. We recognised in 1996 that it was going to be a long process, but we all thought that there was a commitment along the road from a variety of groups in this place and in the community to developing some form of alternative. The evidence gathered to support the contention of the Australian Democrats, young people and unions that higher wages for young people do not lead to increased youth unemployment is quite overwhelming, and people would be familiar with that evidence. Junankar and Waite found that the youth labour market is not an auction market, that once people find work they tend to stay there despite wage relativities, and that changes in economic environments lead to changes in wastage and hiring of new staff—not firing.

talk.start.para: —What did the commission find?

—Through you, Madam Temporary Chairman, Senator Collins was not here when I was reading various responses from the commission to that issue. Her adviser was, and nodded accordingly, so I hope that perhaps she will be filled in subsequently. The OECD Employment Outlook of 1998 found that any negative employment effects for young adults are `generally close to or insignificantly different from zero, and are relatively insignificant in terms of explaining the large decline that has occurred in the teenage employment ratio in some countries'. The Johnson and Mangan study said that, overall, wages do not appear to be a major factor in determining youth employment numbers. Card and Kruger, which is the United States study, finds that increases in the minimum wage were actually accompanied by increases in employment. Other studies back up these findings. There is Katz and Kruger, The effects of minimum wage on the fast food industry , 1992; Spriggs and Klein, The minimum wage: a new assessment of its effects , in 1993; Card, Do minimum wages reduce employment: a case study of California , in 1992; and Dickens et al., Minimum wages and employment: a theoretical framework with an application to the UK wage councils , 1995. The evidence is overwhelming.

speech.para: So what people seem to fail to realise is that not only are youth wages unfair, unnecessary and anachronistic but also many young workers earning youth wages have had far more responsibility on the job than ever was intended when youth wages were conceived on a needs basis early in the century. Their justification for this legislation and for the entrenchment of discrimination on the basis of age is based on unsubstantiated claims that young people might be less mature or less productive than older workers. There has been no sociological or psychological evidence to support this, and it is something to which Senator Murray referred in his earlier remarks. Most young workers are employed in industries which are low skilled and highly casualised. Their flexibility and their quick learning ability make them a perfect work force for these sectors. There is certainly research to prove that. They should be remunerated for the work they do, not according to their age.

I appreciated Senator Sherry coming forward to put his position and the reason that he has voted for this. I am sorry that some other members either were conveniently paired or, to use Senator Ray's expression, did the chicken walk. I end this contribution with a quote from Senator Sherry from November 1996:

I remind the government and the Democrats that junior rates are discriminatory. They permit discrimination between two workers simply on the basis of age, even though they are doing the same work and have the same experience. We are opposed to junior rates, and we thought the Democrats were too.
Boy, how times change.

talk.start.para: —Could I intervene briefly in this debate to indicate to the committee that I am supporting the amendment. I think, however, it is a bit rich for some of the Australian Democrats to reflect on Senator Collins or other honourable senators who have been spending years and years, very often at personal cost, in support of young workers. Coming from a group which supported the first wave of industrial relations intervention—I will not call it reform—by Minister Reith, again it is a bit rich. I do hope that this indicates that the Democrats will not be supporting—I would like to hear this—the second wave of Minister Reith's actions to take away effective protection not only of young workers but also of all workers in Australia.

speech.para: I do apologise for not being here at the last division, but I was in a crucial situation in a committee and I had information that it was not the second reading division. Had I been here, I would have voted against the second reading of this piece of legislation. Again, the outcome of this does not depend on my vote. I am, of course, disappointed that it is likely to get through unamended, and I see no point in expressing my deeply held views under those circumstances. In view of that, I have another committee hearing at half past 12, and I would hope that this committee of the Senate will excuse me for that meeting.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray and Senator Stott Despoja, I am very sorry that you lost your case in the commission. You set up this commission inquiry—
—Direct your comments to the chair, please, Senator.

—I am very sorry that Senator Murray, Senator Stott Despoja and the Australian Democrats feel that they lost their case in the commission. The comments made earlier by Senator Alston are quite accurate. We accepted back in 1996, after the first wave inquiry, that we had to accept the position of the independent umpire. We were outside the deal that the Democrats negotiated with the government on the terms of reference for that inquiry, but we accepted, by the decision of this parliament, that we had to deal with the decision of that independent umpire.

speech.para: It is now obvious, by these amendments and by what has gone forward in the last few weeks, that the Australian Democrats and, to varying degrees, various trade unions did not like that decision. But we indicated—back on 24 June, when we outlined in the House of Representatives our position—that we would ensure the framework that was necessary to implement the commission's decision in its report. So that is the benchmark that Labor is applying, as has earlier been indicated, in our negotiations with the government to rectify its first bill and also in engaging the amendments that have been put forward by the Democrats.

That is the benchmark which I do not think these amendments by the Democrats meet. There are many reasons for this. I will go through some of them as I may not be able to deal with them all in the 15 minutes before we get to non-controversial legislation. My comments will also more accurately reflect some of the commission's report and I will drop in a few words that Senator Stott Despoja dropped out because they were inconvenient.

Firstly, let me go back to a bit of history and then I will comment generally on Senator Murray's amendments. I am sure he will not mind me dealing with the matter in this way as I was handed these amendments only when I was on my feet in the second reading debate. In recent weeks the government has agreed to amend its original bill to reflect the Labor position—the only position—which was to support the independent commission's report, the terms for the inquiry having been framed in the deal between the government and the Democrats. So let us go back to that dirty deal.

Our amendments require the commission to consider both skills, which are critical to this debate, and community standards. Let me answer Senator Murray's question to me of yesterday by stating that we—Labor—believe that age 18 constituting an adult is a widely accepted community standard. That is what we believe is a widely accepted community standard—that is the answer, Senator Murray, to your question of yesterday.

We support the view of the SDA that age 18 is a widely accepted community standard. Where we differ is in the process for implementing that standard. We have accepted—this goes well back—that the commission's decision should determine that framework. That is why we negotiated the outcome we did with the government.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission inquiry into junior rates, as I have said, was initiated by the Democrats. We have consistently argued that we would take on board what the commission had to say. The fact that we have accepted the broad position proposed by the commission is testament to the value we place in it as an independent umpire. I hope that Senator Murray appreciates the right that the Democrats had to appear in that commission inquiry. I have some recollection that, in the first wave of Reith reforms, attempts were made to limit intervention rights in the commission. I hope Senator Murray appreciates that you are going to need to argue those intervention rights if you want to run some of these arguments on a case by case basis in the commission, and I hope you will not compromise them in the second wave.

We believe an independent commission is fundamental to Australian industrial relations. It is fundamental to protecting the position of those who are vulnerable in the labour market. The Labor Party is the only party that respected the independent role of the commission in all of this. The government continued to try and ram through the blanket insertion of junior rates—Minister Alston, that is in response to your earlier comment—and we opposed that with respect to this bill and still do, in line with the commission's report.

The Democrats' response is even more interesting. They say they will do one thing and then do another. They are obviously a bit confused and that confusion is reflected in these amendments. They are the ones that have done the backflip. They are the ones that instigated this inquiry. They are the ones that do not like the result.

As a general principle, we will not be specifying an age. To accept a particular age is to accept that it is okay to discriminate below that age. Senator Murray, my question to you in relation to most of these amendments is: where is the argument from the commission's decision that supports the insertion of an age? There is no argument in that commission report. I will be interested to see how you try to scrounge one up. Any argument that I have heard in the second reading debate so far has been an argument that was presented to the commission; it was not an argument that the commission accepted.

talk.start.para: —Oh, yes, but we do have wonderful evidence in our support.

—I have not seen it yet. In addition, no consideration has been given to the possible disincentive to young people to undertake training such as apprenticeships. A 17-year-old school leaver could undertake a four-year apprenticeship leading to a qualification that will hold them in good stead for the rest of their life. However, consider the difference if a 17-year-old could leave school and undertake unskilled work and, after 12 months, be paid more than a final year apprentice. Isn't this a disincentive for young people? Isn't this the issue the commission needs to consider more closely on a case by case basis, unrestricted by a legislative standard on a particular age?

speech.para: We will not be supporting these amendments. We have our position. That is all I have to say on these amendments, other than to highlight at this stage one issue in respect of the first amendment. As Senator Murray has indicated, this amendment is about a presumption, which we argue is already there. I referred yesterday, pending some preliminary advice from the department, to a section in the report, at page 129, which says:
The desirability of replacing junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives is implicit in the Act.

In respect of the department's role in this matter, let me say that I appreciate their very timely advice following a request I made yesterday. They have gone out of their way to cooperate with the process that the government had established, and any criticism I made yesterday should be clearly directed at the government rather than at the department.

Let me go back to the presumption. I want to go back to the full quote that Senator Stott Despoja referred to. Let us go to page xiii of the commission's summary and what the commission thinks is the task ahead. The commission thinks:
The task is to get right the balance between classification options and two objectives:
. equal opportunity taking account of the competitive disadvantage in employment of school-leavers, teenagers and young employees;
. equality of treatment in employment for all employees taking account of skills, responsibilities, experience and performance.

But here is the crux of the matter: that is not an easy task. I think that is what your common man in the street would expect to be the situation on junior rates. If you looked at any polling, you would probably say that most people would see that balance is important. But the quote from the commission's report states further:
That is not an easy task. It goes to the substance of pay rate classifications, whether age discriminatory or non-discriminatory in form. Age discrimination measures—
which is the word Senator Stott Despoja missed—
present an ill-suited process for that task.
Not `age discrimination', Senator, but `age discrimination measures', and there is a world of difference in the meaning.

Let us look at age discrimination measures, because that is part of the critical problem that the commission's report deals with. In fact, it was so substantial in that report that, rather than reading bold sections of the report, Senator, I suggest you actually go to the appendix, where Justice Munro deals with the critical issues on the matter of discrimination—the critical issues that the commission has big problems with and which the commission says to us that we need to deal with. We need to deal with this problem because the meaning of discrimination as translated in this act is unclear. We need to deal with this crucial matter, senator, that all of your amendments ignore.

Let me deal with the amendment to the act proposed by the government and to the Democrats' amendment. There is nothing in this bill that changes what the commission finds to be the task ahead. It does not change the passage I referred to, which comments that `age discrimination measures present an ill-suited process for the task ahead' for equal opportunity and young employees. That does not change. That is implicit in the act and that survives, Senator, in its full meaning, once you quote it and refer to it fully.

My second question, I suppose, to the Democrats is: why do your amendments not deal with the commission's concern on the meaning of discrimination? The government's amendments do—or the bill does. Why don't the Democrats' amendments deal with that issue? That is the one issue where the commission sought parliamentary guidance. Why don't you? One of the reasons you do not is that you do not like the commission's report and you do not like the measures that various Australian states, and New Zealand, with similar industrial regimes adopted originally. You simply do not like it. You did not convince the commission of your argument, but you do not like the result. They were your terms of reference, negotiated with the government. That was your deal.

In conclusion, let me just clarify in relation to this first amendment—and I will make some brief comments in relation to further amendments—that we believe that the presumption you are suggesting is already implicit in the act. I have indicated the support that exists for that argument in the commission's report. That will be a matter of record for the commission. So we will not be supporting, in particular, this first amendment or the rest of them, because they really do not do much.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Two points I think need to be made. One is that Senator Stott Despoja seems determined to misuse the English language and the logic behind it by arguing that, because the commission somehow did not rule out the possibility of there being some justification or some other way of approaching the issue, the commission itself was therefore endorsing the Democrat amendments. Nothing could be further from the truth.

speech.para: The Democrats' submission to the commission proposed that junior rates be replaced by a competency based wage system and, I say again, the independent umpire comprehensively rejected the Democrat position. So Senator Stott Despoja can twist and turn as much as she likes, but she would be much better off spending less time on undergraduate celebrity humour and a bit more time on a quick course on logic and understanding that it is no justification at all for the Democrat amendments to say that, somehow, the commission was not prepared to rule out the possibility of there being some other feasible alternative. The fact is that the commission found that none of the alternatives to junior wage rates put to it were feasible. Senator Stott Despoja's party had every opportunity to put forward everything they could possibly regard as feasible. Those proposals were rejected. On that basis, I think it is abundantly clear that the Democrats simply have no logical defence to the proposition that they were the ones who wanted the inquiry. They got a result they do not accept and they simply want to have it both ways. So next time they come in here telling us to accept the umpire's decision we will have a very jaundiced view of that proposal.
The other thing I wanted to mention relates to some figures that I want to correct.
Progress reported.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 22 June, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the Commonwealth Grants Commission Amendment Bill 1999 and the amendment to be put forward by Senator Brown, on the understanding and in the hope that it will help improve the provision of services and programs for indigenous peoples.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 33), at the end of section 18, add:
(2) Subsection (1) applies whether or not:
(a) the works or services are provided or funded exclusively in respect of Indigenous persons; or
(b) the financial assistance is applied exclusively in respect of Indigenous persons.

This amendment seeks to ensure that the commission's assessments are not confined to exclusively indigenous spending or money which is exclusively for the indigenous people. Let me point out that the word `indigenous' in my amendment should be spelt with a capitalised `I'. I hope that it will appear in the Hansard as such.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown, I have been advised by the Clerk that that depends on the consistency with other acts.
