I ask: how much will your government have to spend on public relations when Australia becomes an international embarrassment because it leaves athletes with no way of getting around for the Paralympics?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I noticed the press release that Senator Allison put out about the money being spent on the disability access strategy, and I did say to her yesterday that I would get her some information, which I have available here. I will now advise the whole Senate. The information activities are estimated at $370,000. The launch, which includes events in all capital cities, involves $80,000. A symposium series to cover the country comes to $430,000, and the Prime Minister's awards are estimated to cost $225,000. The total estimate is—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. The minister is answering my question from yesterday. There is a time and a place for doing that. I wonder if the minister could be directed to address the question that I asked today.
—I just remind you of today's question, Senator Newman.

—The senator did refer to the $1.2 million strategy, and I think it is very important that people do know how that is spent. Nevertheless, she once again asked me a question which I believe is more appropriately directed to the transport portfolio.
—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer and Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the minister endorse the comment of Mr Costello, who on 1 February 1995 said:

question.para: I mean, look, my analysis is this . . . My analysis is that this is a Government that has completely failed Australia on the current account deficit and produced the highest current account deficit ever, which is a total failure of economic policy. That's my analysis.

Applying the same analysis to goods and services trade, is it not true that on a trend basis over the last 12 months the Howard government has presided over a deficit of $1,250 million per month, which is three times the average over the last 12 months of the Labor government? Isn't Mr Costello's analysis even more correct now in relation to the Howard government's performance on both the current account deficit and the goods and services trade deficit?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —We could have a frank exchange of quotes. I have some quotes here of what you have said over the years.
—Not his famous quote?
—No, the quote which is most relevant to this debate is Senator Cook's third most famous quote.
—`Wake me up before 10 o'clock'?
—No, that is his fourth most famous quote. Senator Cook's third most famous quote was:

answer.para: The current budget—
this was on 23 November 1995, sourced from Hansard —

the budget we brought down in May this year, put the budget into surplus—and not just a surplus this year but also a surplus next year—without there being a contribution to that surplus by asset sales.

What was the end result? Not a surplus, Senator Cook; a major deficit, Senator Cook. That is why, I might say, Senator Cook is often referred to in an affectionate sense as `Senator Cook the books'. Senator, you were not only wrong; you were absolutely dead wrong.

I now turn to the Treasurer's comments. The Treasurer was quite right to point to the disaster of the Labor years, to the fact that virtually every feature of the economy was out of whack and that this economy was being very poorly managed. When this government came in, we very soon faced the worst financial crisis in the world economy really since 1945. As a result of its reforms, as a result of the way it has managed its own books, this government was able to make sure that Australia withstood the downturn in Asia, the downturn in a lot of our export markets. But it is not surprising, in the context of having such a downturn as we have experienced in the Asian region and of having a recession in some of our export markets, that this will have an effect on the balance of payments.

As many other observers have pointed out, the fundamentals in this Australian economy are very sound. They point to the fact that this economy has enjoyed strong growth. The levels of unemployment are falling. The levels of employment are rising. Senator, as we are having a fairly frank exchange of quotes, perhaps I could refer you to the Governor's foreword in the Reserve Bank annual report. He said:

For Australia, it was a good year; although we were caught up in some of the early instability in world financial markets, it was not enough to deflect us from another year of strong economic growth, falling unemployment and low inflation. Australia's performance over the two years since the Asian crisis began has attracted international attention and improved our standing in the international marketplace.

I think that about says it all. This economy is being exceedingly well managed. Senator Cook, when you are faced with a major downturn in your markets, of course that has an effect on your exports. As I said yesterday and the day before—and I will keep on saying it, I suspect—this Australian economy is the envy of many countries around the world, and many independent observers have pointed to the fact that this is an exceedingly well-managed economy.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, Mr Costello and Mr Howard both said that they had fireproofed the Australian economy from the Asian downturn. You now say it is the reason for a $1,250 million deficit per month. Who is right? Mr Costello and Mr Howard? Or are you right and they are wrong? How does the minister explain that for nine months in a row under the Howard government Australia has been running a goods and services trade deficit at more than $1 billion per month?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —You do not have to take my word for the performance of the Australian economy; you do not even have to take the Treasurer's word. But I think you would take the word of the Governor of the Reserve Bank on how the economy has been well managed and how this economy—
—Tell us what he said the other day.

—If Senator George Campbell wants to ask me a question, I think he is quite entitled to ask me a question and we would look forward to a question from Senator George Campbell. What I would say to you, Senator Cook, is: if you don't take my word for it, read what I said in answer to the first part of your question and the comment of the Governor of the Reserve Bank. Senator, I think you should take that as a very sound endorsement of the way this economy is being managed.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Ellison. The minister would be aware of reports regarding Abstudy take-up rates. Would the minister advise the Senate of the Howard government's strong commitment to indigenous education?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Tierney for that important question and acknowledge at the outset his longstanding interest in the education area. I refer to an article in yesterday's Australian , headed `Abstudy take-up rate rises', in which it was noted that demands for Abstudy for tertiary students in the first quarter of this year rose to 16,265 compared with 15,441 for the same period in 1998—that is, for the quarter January-March of this year, there was an increase of 824. In relation to applications, the article noted that in 1998 these rose to 57,985 compared with 56,692 the year before—an increase of just under 1,300. This is good news. It shows that the figures are trending in the right direction, but of course there is much to be done, and the Abstudy Income Assistance Scheme is just one of the many ways that the Howard government is supporting the achievements of educational quality for indigenous people.

answer.para: We have revised Abstudy to improve the targeting of assistance to those students in most need and to open up more opportunities for indigenous students to access a wider range of assistance to obtain improved educational outcomes. There is a record number of indigenous students undertaking tertiary study—in fact, some 7,789 students and a record number of indigenous students involved in traineeships. In addition to the successful Abstudy Income Assistance Scheme, the Commonwealth government currently supports a number of other supplementary programs, including the Higher Education Support Program, VET sector funding arrangements, the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program and the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program. In all, some $388 million in funds is being provided under these programs in this financial year.

One of the key aspects of indigenous education relates to literacy. Under the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program the Commonwealth provides supplementary funding to education providers to address education disadvantages of indigenous students, and in relation to this literacy is a key aspect. This government has reached agreement with the states that all students in years 3 and 5 be able to read and write at the set appropriate standards. By ensuring that indigenous students read and write at appropriate levels, the government will be improving their opportunities to partake in education at senior and post-school levels. This has a direct relevance to the take-up of tertiary education.
In another article in the Australian this week, it was Noel Pearson who stated:
In fact the survival of indigenous culture and knowledge in the long term is going to depend on one thing: literacy.

In relation to that, this government is on track. The former Senator Collins has undertaken a review of education in the Northern Territory, visiting some 44 schools and talking to students, parents and teachers. He himself has stated that the government's initiatives are on track. At the MCEETYA meeting in April this year, state and territory governments agreed to assist the Commonwealth develop a strategy in this regard and endorsed education for indigenous students.

talk.start.para: —Why doesn't the Northern Territory government pull its weight, then?
—Shouting like that is totally out of order, Senator Carr, and you know it.
—It is interesting to hear these interjections. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Can the minister confirm that her department has threatened the peak organisations that it funds, such as Aged Care Australia, the Australian Early Childhood Association and the National Council on Intellectual Disability, with removal of funding unless those organisations `work collaboratively with FACS and provide early warning for all controversial issues planned for media coverage and which might attract public comment'? Can the minister confirm whether she or her staff played any role in having this attempt to stifle criticism from peak bodies inserted by her department in funding conditions? On this occasion, will the minister blame Mr Anthony, her junior minister, as she described him yesterday, or will she perhaps blame her secretary Dr Rosalky, as she has in the past? Just whose fault is it this time, Minister?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I will not blame anybody; in fact, there is nobody to blame. It is a very good process that has been going on in my department with my encouragement to achieve better rationality between all the community organisations.
—You could teach Jeff Kennett a trick or two, couldn't you?

—If the Senate would like to hear the answer to the question, I am very happy to give it. In the establishment of this new portfolio after the last election, programs from a variety of portfolios came together. It was assessed at that time that they were all being funded on a very inconsistent basis. Some were paid substantially more than others, and the conditions on which they were paid were very different and varied quite a lot from how they were treated in other departments again. So there was real room for reform. As a result, there were consultations with the organisations concerned and a new rationale for how they would be funded was proposed. There were pretty reasonable conditions on funding, in my view.
—You don't want to pay the critics, do you?

—I think the senator may be referring to the fact that it was reasonable that, if they were being funded and were working in a position of trust with the department as a result, the department be given a reasonable warning if the issues they had been working on were going to become a matter of public controversy by way of press releases, et cetera. I do not think that is an unreasonable thing; nobody is going to try to censor them.
—Of course you are—you don't like criticism.
—Order! Senator Carr, you have been interjecting too frequently in this question time and I draw your attention to the standing orders.

—I know that most people would regard ACOSS as an organisation which has frequently spoken out over the years in support of ALP measures, and from time to time it speaks out in support of measures of this government—I am glad to say increasingly so as it sees important welfare reforms being introduced for Australians through this government's reform effort. ACOSS has said that it thought it was reasonable for that sort of requirement in exchange for government funding. I think taxpayers would think it was reasonable too.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. If these organisations do not comply with this euphemistic `outcome measure', will the government abolish their funding, as it did with two other groups who stepped out of line—the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, and the Youth Policy and Action Coalition?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Neither of those organisations have been funded by me at any time, so I cannot help you on that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Would the minister please inform the Senate of any recent initiatives which serve to recognise the contribution made by the people of regional Australia to our national life, heritage and economic development?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Lightfoot raises a very important issue. Regrettably, many of the achievements of rural and regional Australia go unnoticed by the broader community. It is not surprising, because in 13 years of Labor government the special needs of country Australia were ignored and the magnificent contribution that regional Australia makes to our economy and to our natural culture was marginalised.

answer.para: I am very proud to say as a regional Australian myself that the same tenacity that allows country people to prevail over natural disasters has allowed them to survive the disasters that Labor inflicted upon them in the bush. So today I applaud a particular initiative that builds on the efforts of a dedicated group of country people to have the year 2002 designated as the Year of the Outback. I say that this initiative is driven by the people of the outback themselves and so it has a lot of very good ideas. I want to specifically recognise Mr Bruce Campbell MBE, who proposed that a year should be designated as the Year of the Outback to promote the outback and its contribution to the nation's economic, social and cultural life.

I am very pleased that the Prime Minister has become an ardent supporter of this, and Mr Anderson, the Deputy Prime Minister, and a number of my coalition colleagues joined in approaching the Prime Minister to ensure that the year 2002 was designated as the Year of the Outback. In fact, I understand that this initiative has bipartisan support in Queensland, so senators opposite might actually like to take the Queensland lead and hopefully join in and support this. Some could perhaps make a first visit to some parts of the outback. Perhaps you can do that in 2002 if you do not get around to it before. Now that the Labor Party are free and liberated, not concerned or constrained by policy development these days, you will have the whole next 18 months to look at your diaries—

talk.start.para: —Senator Macdonald, your remarks should be addressed to the chair and not across the chamber.

—So the Labor Party will be able to work on their diaries for the next 18 months; they have got nothing else to do these days. I urge Labor senators to remember that the year 2002 will be the Year of the Outback. We have decided to endorse plans to make 2002 an official Australian Year of the Outback and we will be helping with some funds to develop plans for this proposal.

answer.para: This initiative just adds to the other initiatives of the coalition government and achievements for the bush. We have provided $70 million for rural transaction centres; we have provided $20 million so far for providing basic information and Internet assistance through the Rural Communities Program; and we are providing $16 million for regional tourism programs to help country tourist destinations attract more tourists. My colleague Senator Alston and the government have provided $250 million to Networking the Nation, to provide telecommunications additions for people in the bush. We are providing a new mobile phone service. You might remember the old analog service that the Labor government cancelled as of this year. Senator Alston, his department and Senator Campbell in that area have given an alternative to people in the bush that the Labor Party simply ignored. We have provided money for multipurpose centres; and so the work goes on. This government is interested in rural and regional Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. I refer the leader to the fear campaign generated by the Minister for Employment Services over the eligibility of British subjects to vote in the forthcoming referendum on the republic, particularly his comments that this amounts to ethnic cleansing and vote rigging. Isn't the minister wrong in suggesting that there is a threat to these subjects' right to vote? Rather, isn't the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison, correct when he says that all political parties are of a view that it would be `unfair to disenfranchise British subjects who are already enrolled'? What steps will the Prime Minister take to counsel Mr Abbott against such irrational conduct and to ensure a careful, temperate consideration of the issues?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Bolkus is confused in his question. As I understand the matter, another individual said that these particular individuals should not be entitled to vote and Mr Abbott said they should. In this instance I agree with Mr Abbott.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I think it is fair to anticipate the Leader of the Government trying to fudge this issue and dodge it, but the fact of the matter is that it was Minister Abbott who made comments about ethnic cleansing and vote rigging. Will the Leader of the Government agree that Mr Abbott's comments are intended to generate fear? Don't they also offend many Australians who have been the real victims, or their families have, of ethnic cleansing? Shouldn't the minister also apologise to these decent Australians for his intemperate behaviour?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I might say it was a typically colourful expression used by Mr Abbott. There may have been a better expression, but on the other hand the substance of what he was saying was quite reasonable, and that is that these Australians born in Britain should be entitled to vote.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs: Funding

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Given that this year the Howard government's indigenous specific funding is at a record high of $2.2 billion, can the minister please explain what are the expected outcomes of this major socioeconomic investment in Australia?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for the question and for her continued interest in this portfolio.
—Give us a quote.
—I hear the other side asking me for a quote. Yes, I am happy to give a quote to the other side. It is a quote from the Courier-Mail 's political editor, Craig Johnson, who said this week:

answer.para: Labor's philosophy towards Aboriginal policy remains little changed from the days of Hindmarsh Island and the hapless Robert Tickner.

You asked for a quote, Senator Campbell, and I give you one. I give Senator Campbell one, Madam President. It must be fairly obvious to everybody that the Labor Party have lost touch with the indigenous community and the indigenous leadership. The most recent example of this has been Labor's churlishness in the past fortnight. Instead of looking to the future and moving forward with the united Australia, the country has witnessed Labor doing the time warp. This is Labor at their worst, as they cling to the bad old days, promoting the same old political rhetoric. They are lost but they are freely lost, as the cartoon in today's Canberra Times says.

talk.start.para: —Senator Herron, it is out of order to be showing pieces of paper like that.
—They said they are lost, and I understand they are lost in Aboriginal affairs too.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! It is out of order for senators to be making so much noise and shouting across the chamber.
—Take the New Zealanders out!
—Senator Faulkner, I have just drawn senators' attention to their behaviour.
—Thank you, Madam President.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht, your behaviour is unacceptable.

—Instead of thinking about the interests of indigenous Australians, Labor is playing the role of the spoiler and the newly liberated opposition leader has confirmed this stance in today's press with his comments that Labor is prepared to `die in a ditch' on issues.

answer.para: There has been a sea change in indigenous affairs in this country in the past 3½ years. There is a convergence of views moving in time with the government's policies of focusing on the key areas of health, housing, education, employment and economic empowerment. There can be no question that indigenous Australians are among the most disadvantaged in our community and, while money alone is not the answer, we are committing record levels of funding to specific programs that will address that disadvantage. Seventy per cent of the $2.2 billion budget this year is going on health, housing, education and employment programs for indigenous Australians.

Labor provided a great deal of funding but had little or no interest in outcomes. Labor was happy to perpetuate welfare dependency, while we are determined to remove the welfare shackles that have bound indigenous Australians for far too long. We are beginning to see substantial improvements in many of the key areas of disadvantage. For example, four years ago there were just 800 indigenous Australians doing apprenticeships or traineeships, and today there are 4,800. Twenty years ago, only 8.6 per cent of indigenous students stayed at school until their final year; today over 33 per cent finish school and that figure continues to rise. A decade ago, there were 1,600 university students; today there are almost 9,000.

The indigenous infant mortality rate is of great concern but even in this area things are improving. Twenty years ago, the indigenous infant mortality rate was more than 20 times that of the wider community; today it is three to four times higher. This is an area we will continue addressing, particularly in remote communities where there has always been a lack of antenatal care, and over the past three years we have provided 35 additional Aboriginal medical services, mostly in remote areas. Indigenous health funding has quadrupled over the past decade.

There are some on the other side of this chamber and in the community who are determined to continue playing politics with indigenous affairs. If all the resources and energy that have gone into politicising indigenous affairs in recent years had instead been directed towards addressing the problems of disadvantage, we would be so much further along the road to equality than we now are.

In closing, I want to commend the repartee of the Democrats' spokesman in relation to Mr Beazley speaking about the cock crowing three times and the Democrats being irrelevant. The Democrats' spokesman said that the Labor Party would not hear it because they would be all asleep in the garden of Gethsemane. It is fairly obvious, Madam President, that not only are they freely liberated; they are freely liberated and asleep. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam President, on 31 August Senator Gibbs asked a question about whether the accommodation charge is indexed and whether it will increase. I seek leave to incorporate the reply from the minister in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
INDEXATION OF THE ACCOMMODATION CHARGE—(60)
Senator Gibbs (ALP) has asked whether the accommodation charge is indexed, and whether it will increase (Senate Hansard 31 August 1999)
. Protections for residents who pay the accommodation charge for nursing home accommodation are set out in the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 .
. This Bill was to be passed in June this year, but was delayed by the Opposition.

. When the Bill passes through the Senate and is proclaimed, it will enable a regulation to be made to provide for an indexation mechanism for the accommodation charge that will ensure that the maximum accommodation charge does not rise in real terms.

. Indexation of the accommodation charge will occur in July each year, in line with indexation of other accommodation payment amounts, such as retention amounts for accommodation bonds, and Commonwealth residential subsidies.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government (Senator Ian Macdonald) to questions without notice asked by Senators Mackay and O'Brien today, relating to stevedoring charges.

We saw yesterday in the House of Representatives Minister Reith misleading the House and causing uproar in question time over the alleged role of senators in relation to refusing to deal with legislation now before this chamber. But, frankly, one only has to look at the record of Mr Reith to see that he has been a serial misleader. In relation to the stevedoring levy, when Mr Reith held a press conference on 8 April 1998 to announce the levy and the benchmarks that he had set for reform in the waterfront industry, he was asked, `Mr Reith, can you say that stevedores won't pass on the costs of the levy?' Mr Reith said, `I've got it in writing from them.'

Of course, when we held the first hearing into the stevedoring levy bill, the bill that was subsequently passed by the Senate, both stevedores—Patrick and P&O—absolutely denied, categorically denied, that they had given Mr Reith any commitment in writing that they would absorb the stevedoring levy. But what did we find out at the hearing last Friday into the proposed amendment to the stevedoring levy bill? We found out that not only did he not get the undertaking from the stevedores that he said he had in writing in relation to the absorption of the levy but also he did not even seek, either written or even orally, an undertaking from those stevedores that they would—given the enormous support from the taxpayer through Mr Reith's discredited waterfront strategy and given the enormous pain that strategy had caused the whole of the community—pass on part of their cost savings to shippers.

The evidence that we had from Mr Corrigan last Friday and certainly from the department was not only have cost savings not being passed on; Mr Corrigan said absolutely and categorically that there had been no such request from Mr Reith. Given all the pain that the community went through, given the costs that were incurred by parts of the shipping industry, given the costs to the community of that discredited dispute, why wouldn't the minister seek from the stevedores, who are getting substantial benefits from this government and this government's strategy, some assurance that there would be some immediate benefit?

Indeed, Mr Reith said the benefits would be apparent within six months. We are now near enough to 18 months out from that strategy and there are no benefits in terms of financial ones. Whatever the so-called productivity benefits, there are no benefits to shippers. From what we have seen, the likelihood is that the costs of the shipping companies will rise, that their charges will rise, and that stevedoring charges are unlikely to fall in the next seven to eight years. That is the evidence from Mr Corrigan. What Mr Corrigan is saying now is that the dispute cost him $70 million and he wants to recover that and another $30 million in so-called `opportunity costs' before he will consider passing those cost savings on.

In relation to the question asked about the benefits flowing through in share prices, you have only to look at the Lang Corporation's share price and compare it with the share price before the reforms were announced to see just where the benefits are. Those benefits reflected in the Lang Corporation's share price were at $1.50 before the measures. Today, in the Financial Review, the share price of Lang Corporation is shown at $5.35. So all the benefit is going to the shareholders of the Lang Corporation.

talk.start.para: —Good!

—If Senator McGauran agrees with that, and that is the form of this government, then what he is saying is that they are happy that the only beneficiaries of this so-called reform will be shareholders of the Lang Corporation, not the shippers, the farmers or the manufacturers—no-one, unless they hold shares in the Lang Corporation. The government may think that is a good thing, but I will tell you that Mr Frank Beaufort said of Mr Corrigan that Nelson's arm would grow back before Corrigan lowered his prices. (Time expired)

—If you listened to the Australian Labor Party during question time and if you listened to Senator O'Brien in this debate on his motion to take note of answers given by Senator Ian Macdonald during question time today—

speech.para: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —and if you listened to the interjections during question time, Senator Ferguson, you would think that the Labor Party wanted to move to the situation we had on the waterfront prior to the introduction of the reforms. One would expect the Labor Party to suggest that the process of that reform was not the way they would do it. We saw how they would do it: they had a distinguished former senator, Bob Collins, the minister at the time, who said that he would resign if they did not achieve it within a year, or whatever it was.
—He did—eight years later.
—He retired of his own volition eight years later. I do not think it had anything to do with waterfront reform; I think he was sick and tired of sitting on aeroplanes.
—You're struggling and you are only 30 seconds into it.

—It is very hard for Senator George Campbell to contemplate reform in any workplace. So when you have a substantial reform of an Australian workplace that sees productivity levels go through the roof, where good Australian workers have lifted their productivity massively because of sound reforms from a coalition government, it must really hurt Senator George Campbell. So what the Labor Party say is, `If you don't have significant reductions in stevedoring charges, why was it worth it?' The fact that you can get a ship in and turn it around at double the speed that you could do it a year ago is, apparently, no good for Australia. The Labor Party would rather have the ships lined up off Australian ports—the good old Labor days when you could drive down past Fremantle and look out across Gage Roads and see dozens of ships anchored there. Or you could look out off Newcastle and see dozens of ships queuing up, or dozens of ships off the port of Sydney, off Cairns or off any of the ports around Australia, waiting for the latest strike to be over.

speech.para: Those were the good old Labor days; those are the days that Senator O'Brien and his comrades yearn for. Let us get back to good industrial relations where we have two or three times the number of people you need per job. Let us have crane rates in single figures not double figures. Let us shift containers at the rate of one or two an hour, or nine an hour if you are lucky, or double figures if it is a really good day. What did we do? We set a benchmark of 25 containers an hour, and they say, `How dare you? You can't do that. Twenty-five containers in an hour, how could you ever do that with half the people?'

Madam Deputy President, you know where the Labor Party stand on this; they do not want the reform process to succeed. But the reality is that poor old Senator O'Brien opposite cannot even get his facts straight. He said that crane and stevedoring charges are going up. He is misquoting Senator Corrigan—

talk.start.para: —Oh, yes, Senator Corrigan!

—He would make a much better senator than Senator O'Brien does. I have never had the great pleasure of meeting Mr Corrigan. I would love to meet him because I think he is a truly great Australian. The Democrats might even try to get him to be a candidate. As to the evidence he gave to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on 27 August last, which I think Senator O'Brien referred to, I am informed that Mr Corrigan said:

speech.para: The facts are that our stevedoring charges have declined.

talk.start.para: —Over the last 12 years, not now.

—That is what he said: `The facts are that our stevedoring charges have declined.' Let us just put that aside. Let Senator O'Brien and Mr Corrigan have an argument about stevedoring rates. What the Labor Party says is that if stevedoring rates go down, you have not had improvements for Australia. What the Labor Party is saying is that if you can double the crane rates, turn the ships around, ensure that international transport firms, shipping companies and exporters and importers know that they can come into Australian ports with far more confidence—that is, get in, get the cranes going, get the containers shifted and get out again—that is not good for Australia. Of course it is good for Australia. We are a trading nation. We have to be a trading nation and we need an efficient waterfront. We need the productivity increases, and that is what has been achieved, absolutely regardless of stevedoring costs. Of course, the government does not and will not accept Senator O'Brien's affirmation that he believes stevedoring charges have gone up. There have been significant productivity increases. That is a big win for Australian importers and, very importantly, it is a big win for Australian exporters. (Time expired)

—I feel a bit sorry for Senator Ian Campbell because he got handed that brief very late in the piece by the minister who represents Minister Anderson, Senator Ian Macdonald, and who scarpered out of the chamber at double time. I think Senator Campbell did have to rely on a bit of the old class warfare rhetoric from the government in trying to pad out the five minutes. I think it would have been reasonable for the representing minister to have stayed and used the briefing notes himself and to have responded to some of the questions raised by the opposition considering that he seemed, as we now see, to have had those briefs in his folder, to the extent that he was able to give them to poor old Senator Ian Campbell over there.

speech.para: I think it is extraordinary that it took Senator Macdonald until about the third question to find the brief, and the brief that he used was the general brief, not the one that dealt with the legislation hearing which was held last week. This is not unexpected of this particular minister. I exhort this minister to read the briefs that the department provides him with, because I think he would find them illuminating and he would be somewhat less embarrassed at question time.

Senator Macdonald stated in very general terms that the real winners and the real beneficiaries of the waterfront policy were the people of Australia. `They are the real winners.' Nowhere in his response did he defend the government's setting of the benchmarks. Nowhere did he say, `You are wrong, Senator Mackay. You are wrong, Senator O'Brien. We have met the benchmarks.'

Senator Newman may say, `Trust me, I'm from the government.' We say that, if you do not trust us, have a look at what the department itself said. Officials from the department conceded that the benchmarks that the government had set were not met. The department has conceded that. I will be interested to hear Senator McGauran's comments on that.

Let me go to the comments that Senator Ian Campbell made when he was very hurriedly rushed in to respond, and he selectively quoted from Mr Corrigan's evidence at the hearings last Friday. Let me quote what Mr Corrigan said. In a line of questioning from Senator O'Brien as to whether the government ever required the reduction of costs or the productivity gains to be manifested in terms of reduction of stevedoring costs, he said, `No, they weren't.' Senator O'Brien, who clearly could not believe his ears, asked:
They have never asked you for any commitments to that?
That is, a commitment to a reduction of the stevedoring costs. Mr Corrigan said:
No, because otherwise I imagine they might have put it in the seven benchmark objectives.
I would say QED. Senator O'Brien goes on, again somewhat incredulous as to the nature of this evidence:
I am not trying to put words into your mouth—
and he wasn't; I was there—
I am asking for the information, Mr Corrigan.
Mr Corrigan said:
I am sure that as part of the overall improvements in efficiency they had an expectation that that would occur—
The government had an expectation. Mr Corrigan continued:
It has been occurring for 12 years. Stevedoring charges are less than 50 per cent in real terms of what they were 12 years ago.
So much for Senator Macdonald's allegation that nothing happened under Labor. This is Mr Corrigan conceding a major reduction in stevedoring levies. Mr Corrigan continued:
I expect that to go on. I am sure they expected it to go on.
`They' being the government. He continued:
Did they precisely attempt to negotiate with us our stevedoring prices? The answer is no, they did not.
That is evidence from Mr Corrigan himself that the government did not seek an assurance in relation to reduction of stevedoring costs.

talk.start.para: —So what?

—Senator McGauran says, `So what.' Because Minister Reith, Minister Anderson and the Prime Minister said it would happen. At that time, they said one of the reasons this extraordinary action was being taken was so that costs of stevedoring levies to shippers and to the Australian community would be reduced. It has not happened.
—It has.
—It has not happened. Costs have not been reduced in relation to stevedoring, so, QED, the government is wrong on two points. (Time expired)
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President.
—This will be good!

—Senator Carr interjects first up. Senator Carr was seen backing the MUA at an illegal picket at the Webb Dock, hand in hand with his MUA masters. He was on the front page of the Age . You should be ashamed of yourself, Senator Carr. If I remember rightly, you also encour aged the bringing of children down to that particular picket line. You were up to this strike—up to the disgraceful tactics of the MUA—from day one. You are not free at last, Senator Carr; you are still the master of the MUA. They are still your little icons. Why don't you listen to Mr Beazley? Free yourself, Senator Carr.

speech.para: I have heard many indefensible efforts by the opposition, but this would have to be the greatest job of trying to defend the indefensible I have yet heard from the other side. The opposition come in here and suggest that the reforms that have been achieved down at the waterfront have not been reforms at all and that they have not been worth while. They even suggest we should return to the bad old days, that it has not been worth it. Nothing has been more worth it in this government's reform achievements than what we did down on the waterfront. I would go so far as to say that these achievements have had much to do with sustaining this country's economy throughout the last three months. They have been part of the miracle economy and have helped buffet us against the Asian crisis. Down at the waterfront, we have not had the national strikes that we are so used to.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr, what I did notice about that shock that we all `had to have' down at the waterfront was that the other unions did not go out. That had much to do with this government's returning of the secondary boycott laws. Because of those laws and those reforms, we were able to contain the waterfront strike to just that. We did not have the damaging national strikes where the transport union used to go out in sympathy and tie up this whole country.

speech.para: The opposition comes in here and suggests that those reforms have not brought stability and certainty, which is a natural flow-on effect in itself. We have improvement in turnaround times with the shipping and with trucks. There have been improvements and they all cascade into lower costs.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They have. If you are suggesting that we seek more competition amongst the stevedoring sector, we do. We would like to see many more stevedoring firms set up against P&O and Patrick—and so there should be—but no new stevedoring firm was ever going to set up until we brought those reforms in. Within the next five years we will probably get new entrants onto the waterfront to bring competition to Patrick and to P&O. Then you will see even further tumbling. But to suggest that there has been no reduction in the pricing down on the waterfront is absurd. You refuse to look at this objectively. One of this government's great reforms is the waterfront. The winners have been the national economy, the exporters and the importers, and that has a flow-on effect through to every level of our economy, right down to the consumer. Our national reputation has been lifted because we have introduced certainty and we are not getting the strikes that we used to. Even the MUA workers have benefited.
—What about the workers?

—They are earning more now than they did before. That is the irony of all this. Because we attached the reforms to productivity, you will find that more work is being done with fewer workers, and the workers are working. They are not slaves to the MUA bosses anymore; they have incentive payments. They are as happy as can be, and that is why they are not going out on strike. You tried to bring in reform and you failed. Hawke's late night meetings with the MUA achieved nothing and we wasted $420 million. The seven benchmarks that the government introduced—and time does not permit me to go through them all—have been met.
—They have not.
—If time permitted, I could tick each one of them off. The first one is crane rates, Senator O'Brien. We have achieved the 25 crane lifts per hour. That is the first benchmark. Do you deny that?
—The Melbourne docks deny that.
—Down in the Melbourne docks we are lifting 32 per hour. I do not know why you bring this issue in. You bring it in only because you are trying to re-establish your union credentials. (Time expired)

—I want to make a number of comments in relation to this issue and the answers—or the lack of answers—from Senator Macdonald in respect of the questions asked about waterfront reform. I will start off by addressing the issue of reform, which each of the speakers on the other side of the chamber has referred to—the reform that they introduced and the lack of reform that took place under the last Labor government.

speech.para: What did Mr Corrigan say at the hearing last Friday that belies that issue, that puts that myth to rest? He said in response to Senator O'Brien's questioning that the charges on the waterfront had been falling for 12 years—which in fact was during the period of the Labor government—and the charges have not fallen from when you initiated your great reform process on the waterfront.

talk.start.para: —Redundancy payments.

—They have not fallen. Charges fell over the previous 12 years down to half of what they were 12 years ago. That is Mr Corrigan's evidence. Let me back that up by informing the Senate of some comments with respect to waterfront reform that were made by another great Australian. They were made at a hearing of the Australian Manufacturing Council back in about the early 1990s when they had a presentation on the reform process that was occurring on the waterfront. The comments were made by Mr John Prescott, who was then the Chief Executive of BHP. He said that he would not, if he had the capacity to do it, take one of his ships through the port of Melbourne because none of the cost savings that had been achieved in the stevedoring industry as a result of reforms instituted by the Labor government had been passed through by the stevedores, and he said, `I know what the savings are, because I run stevedoring companies.' What the stevedoring companies were doing—and what Mr Corrigan is now doing—was using the benefits of the changes that have occurred on the waterfront, which were implemented by the Labor government and almost buggered up by you mob—
—Order! Please do not swear. Watch your language, Senator.
—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that that be withdrawn. In the spirit of the debate, I do not want to waste his time, but I think he should withdraw it.
—If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw it.
—Thank you, Senator George Campbell.

—They were almost destroyed by the actions of your mob in the waterfront dispute. But the reality is that the benefits that have come out of reforms that have been taking place on the waterfront since the mid-1960s—not a recent event—have all accrued, at the end of the day, to the stevedoring companies. That is evident from what Senator O'Brien said in terms of the share price of the Lang Corporation as of today and before the process started.

speech.para: The reality is that you need something to justify your actions, because what has occurred since 1998 on the waterfront has done nothing other than reinforce the view that was expressed at the time: that your dispute on the waterfront was an ideological dispute. It was an ideological dispute generated by your hatred of organised labour. You had a willing companion in that process in Chris Corrigan. You went to extraordinary lengths—

talk.start.para: —And we won.

—You went to extraordinary lengths to try to reform the waterfront. You took people in the dead of night to Dubai to train them. You sent the thugs in with the balaclavas. I want to correct what Senator Macdonald, in response to one of the questions, put on the record about the thugs being from the MUA. The thugs were from Corrigan's Patrick stevedoring company. They were the people who went in in the dead of night with the dogs and the balaclavas and pitched people out of their legitimate employment—and your government acquiesced in that.
—They were part of the conspiracy.
—You were part of the conspiracy, as Senator Carr said. You did not win.
—Address the chair, please, Senator George Campbell.
—Madam Deputy President, they did not win. (Time expired)

—I would like to begin my contribution, since quoting is the order of the day, by reading another quote from page 24. The Labor Party have been selectively quoting from page 25 of the hearings, but there is a question on page 24 by Senator O'Brien in which he asks:

speech.para: Without putting on the public record specific numbers, can you tell the committee whether there has been an overall increase or decrease in your stevedoring charges to shipping companies since the beginning of 1998?
That is not 12 years. The answer from Mr Corrigan is:

In answering that question I would like to avoid relying on hearsay. I would like to avoid relying on anecdotal evidence and I would not be going to a survey of client expectations. I will give you the facts. The facts are that our stevedoring charges have declined.

When you come into this place and you selectively quote, as the Labor Party has, you want to be pretty careful about what you are saying because, in fact, the answer is right there which refutes your proposition.

Also, at the hearings Mr Corrigan said he would give us an index of the charges over the years. Also, because I asked for this from P&O after the hearing—after they had shown us a graph there—they will be sending us a similar graph which will show a continuous decline for a number of years. I am not sure whether that is 12 years with P&O. It is certainly beyond 1998. But it also shows that, since 1998, in the last couple of years, the falls have continued consistently.

There was evidence given to us in information that I have that, in fact, in the Australian shipping arena—and it is in the evidence here—we have cheaper stevedoring charges than in Hong Kong and in America. Mr Corrigan put that on the table. But he also said that, since the time of this reform, we have seen a significant improvement in the turnaround time of ships in Australian ports. He also gave evidence which said that in some instances there were fewer ships doing the run now but doing the same job—that is, carting a similar tonnage of cargo.

You must take the whole context. Mr Corrigan made the point that, in the overall Australian scene, a relatively small part of the total costs is involved in stevedoring. The people on the other side of this chamber know this, but they wanted to do a beat-up on one page of the hearings with some answers to some specific questions. If there were a little more honesty with the answers, or more description or more detail, they would paint the full picture. We sat there all day. But they have taken a couple of questions and have tried to do a beat-up on Mr Corrigan. I find that absolutely irresponsible. The facts are different.

The failure of the Labor Party's reforms—and I have never said it in this place, and I am not aware of others who have sat on this side of parliament who have said that there were not issues addressed in terms of stevedoring and the numbers and the arrangements—is the failure to address the turnaround time of ships. They failed to address the time they were in ports. They failed to address the number of ships that were tied up waiting to get into port because there was a ship held up. All these things are additional parts of the cost.

Finally, I would like to deal with one particular aspect. Senator Mackay—in one of these funny little nitpicking things she gets herself into—chose to have a crack at Minister Macdonald because he was not in the chamber at a particular time. Ministers, like everybody else, are busy people, and he obviously had to go and do something. But it is worth noting that, no sooner had Senator Mackay finished her contribution, she was off from here like a rat up a drainpipe. She was just gone. If you are going to call the kettle black on this side, you had better have a look at the bottom of the pot on your side before you do it. That is a very unfair thing to do in the context of this debate.

I say to those on the other side of the chamber that they must look at this against the benchmarks. They must take them into consideration and report accurately what was said. I am surprised that Senator O'Brien did this because it was he who asked the questions, and nobody else. He asked the question, and I will repeat the answer:

In answering the question I would like to avoid relying on hearsay. I would like to avoid relying on anecdotal evidence. I would not be going to a survey of client expectations. I will give you the facts. The facts are that our stevedoring charges have declined.
Senator O'Brien's question to the company specified the time since the beginning of 1998. That was the whole context of it.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.
